question: When must a Petroleum Reporting Entity ensure that its disclosures regarding Petroleum Resources comply with the specified standards and rules?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must ensure that any disclosure it makes, which includes statements about Petroleum Resources such as estimates of Petroleum Reserves, Contingent Resources, or Prospective Resources, is prepared in accordance with the Petroleum Reporting Standard and Chapter 12 of the Rules. This obligation applies to all disclosures made or required to be made under these Rules, encompassing various documents and formats such as Prospectuses, Exempt Offer documents, bidders and targets statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content. The comprehensive scope ensures that all relevant disclosures are consistent and adhere to the established standards, thereby maintaining transparency and accuracy in reporting. This requirement is crucial for ensuring that stakeholders receive reliable and standardized information regarding Petroleum Resources, which is essential for informed decision-making and regulatory compliance [#SRC:10c4f550-6148-4206-98ad-0bb8caf45c8d] and [#TGT:8d5ce59f-c53f-441b-ae74-4dade81dfb4a].

question: What requirements must the Board and its committees of a Reporting Entity and a Listed Entity fulfill to ensure an appropriate balance of skills and resources?
expected_answer: The Board and its committees of both a Reporting Entity and a Listed Entity are required to maintain an appropriate balance of skills, experience, independence, and knowledge relevant to their respective businesses. This balance is essential to ensure effective governance and decision-making processes. Additionally, they must have adequate resources, which include access to necessary expertise and timely, comprehensive information about the entity's affairs. This requirement is part of Principle 3 concerning Board composition and resources, which underscores the importance of having a well-rounded and informed Board to oversee the entity's operations effectively. The annual report of the Reporting Entity should also identify key figures such as the chairman and chief executive, and outline the decision-making responsibilities of the Board versus those delegated to Senior Management. These measures collectively aim to enhance the governance framework by ensuring that the Board is equipped with the necessary tools and information to fulfill its obligations effectively [#SRC:35277484-31bd-49fe-956c-02f3ceff5405] and [#TGT:705e3965-3995-437d-abe7-8af619b6bbbb].

question: Under what conditions must a Listed Entity seek approval from the holders of its Ordinary Securities for a Related Party Transaction, and what procedural steps must be followed if the transaction value meets or exceeds a specified threshold?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must seek approval from the holders of its Ordinary Securities for a Related Party Transaction when the transaction value is equal to or greater than 5% of the net assets of the Listed Entity, as stated in its most recent financial reports. This approval must be obtained from a majority of the Shareholders before entering into the transaction. If the transaction value is below this threshold, the entity must notify the Regulator of the transaction terms and provide written confirmation from an independent third party that the terms are fair and reasonable. Additionally, the transaction must be disclosed in accordance with specific rules. If a series of transactions with the same Related Party cumulatively reaches the 5% threshold within a 12-month period, the last transaction in the series must also receive Shareholder approval. Furthermore, if there is a material change to the terms of a transaction after obtaining initial Shareholder approval, the entity must seek approval again. Related Parties and their Associates must abstain from voting on the resolution for approval [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de].

debug_context.target_text: Related Party Transaction procedures. A Listed Entity must ensure that: (1) if the value of a proposed Related Party Transaction is equal to or greater than 5% of the value of the net assets of the Listed Entity as stated in its most recent financial reports, it does not enter into such a transaction unless the proposed transaction has been put to Shareholder approval and has received prior approval by a majority of the Shareholders of the Listed Entity; (2) if the value of the proposed Related Party Transaction is less than the 5% threshold referred to in (1), the Reporting Entity must as soon as possible after entering the transaction: (a) notify the Regulator of the relevant terms and the basis on which such terms are considered fair and reasonable, supported by written confirmation by an independent third party; and (b) Disclose the Related Party Transaction in accordance with Rule 7.7.1; (3) if the cumulative value of a series of Related Party Transactions with the same Related Party which have not received Shareholder approval reaches the 5% threshold referred to in (1) in any 12 month period, it does not enter into the last of the series of the transactions unless such proposed action has been put to Shareholder approval and received approval by a majority of the Shareholders in voting of the Listed Entity; (4) if, after obtaining Shareholder approval pursuant to Rule 9.5.3(1) but before the completion of the Related Party Transaction, there is a material change to the terms of the proposed transaction, the Listed Entity must comply again separately with Rule 9.5.3(1) in relation to the Related Party Transaction; or (5) the Related Party does not vote on the Shareholder resolution referred to in Rule 9.5.3(1) and takes all reasonable steps to ensure that any Related Party Associates of the relevant Related Party also do not vote on the Shareholder resolution.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity uses forecast financial information to determine a Production Target, what must be included in the disclosure about economic assumptions and their sensitivity?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must include specific information in its disclosure when using forecast financial information to determine a Production Target. This includes all material economic assumptions used in the process. If these assumptions are considered commercially sensitive, the entity must state this and explain the methodology behind them. Additionally, all other material assumptions must be disclosed. The entity must also ensure that the Production Target, which is the basis for the forecast financial information, contains all necessary details as required [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] and permitted [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. This comprehensive disclosure helps stakeholders understand the assumptions behind the financial forecasts and assess their credibility and potential impact.

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; or (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. (3) the proportions of the Production Target based on: (a) Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves; (b) Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources; (c) Inferred Mineral Resources; and (d) an Exploration Target. (4) a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan; (5) if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources: (a) an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources; (b) the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence; (c) a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and (d) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised. The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.” Guidance Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement. The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources. (6) if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When a final notice is issued, what must it include to ensure the obligation to make a payment is enforceable as a debt if the payment is not made by the specified date?
expected_answer: A final notice must comprehensively detail the financial penalty, including the exact amount and the deadline for payment, to ensure enforceability of the payment obligation as a debt. This requirement is crucial because if the payment is not made by the specified date, the obligation becomes enforceable as a debt by the entitled person. Additionally, the final notice should specify any applicable suspension, limitation, or restriction periods, and outline the terms of any statement to be published. In cases where restitution is ordered in the form of payment, the notice must clearly state the amount to be paid or distributed, identify the recipients, and describe the payment or distribution arrangements. These procedural elements ensure that the notice is comprehensive and that the payment obligation is legally enforceable [#SRC:98fb6898-5355-4c14-b332-e120dcbff722] [#TGT:e6a2d41b-716b-42a8-ae2d-d7f1a822a015].

question: What must a Recognised Clearing House do to make sure that designated people or groups don't harm the market if they fail to meet their obligations, and how should they handle the designation process?
expected_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must have procedures to ensure that designated people or groups do not harm the market if they fail to meet their obligations under Market Contracts. These procedures should include steps for designating people or groups, regularly reviewing who should be designated, and removing designations when needed. This helps prevent any negative impact on the market's operation. The procedures must ensure that no one remains designated if their failure to meet obligations could hurt the market. By managing the designation process carefully, the Recognised Clearing House can protect the market from risks associated with non-compliance by those who are designated [#SRC:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b] and [#TGT:242b0395-19a9-4471-85cb-e31dac7eae5d].

debug_context.source_text: The procedures in Rule 4.5.9 must be designed to ensure that: (a) a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by him to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market; and (b) a description of persons is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by a Person of that description to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect operation of the market.
debug_context.target_text: If such provision is made as allowed under Rule 4.5.8, the Recognised Clearing House must have adequate procedures for: (a) designating the Persons, or descriptions of person, in respect of whom action may be taken; (b) keeping under review the question which Persons or descriptions of person should be or remain so designated; and (c) withdrawing such designation.

answer_spans.text: If such provision is made as allowed under Rule 4.

question: What is the nature of Guidance issued under the Financial Services and Markets Regulations, and how does it relate to the Rules and Market Rules of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority?
expected_answer: Guidance issued under the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) is characterized as indicative and non-binding. It serves as a supplementary tool to the FSMR and the Market Rules of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA). This Guidance can take the form of notations made and issued by the Regulator to accompany the Rules, or it may consist of separate Guidance issued by the Regulator that has not been incorporated into the Rules. The purpose of such Guidance is to provide clarity and direction without imposing mandatory requirements, thereby allowing for flexibility in interpretation and application. This approach ensures that while the Guidance aids in understanding the regulatory framework, it does not carry the force of law, thus maintaining its non-binding nature. The issuance of Guidance under section 15(2) of the FSMR underscores its role in facilitating compliance and understanding within the financial services sector, while not constraining the regulated entities with additional binding obligations [#SRC:21eef1b0-cc53-4b57-bc5b-7aabd21ef37f] [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd].

question: When can the Regulator let a Recognised Investment Exchange delay making trade details public, and what must the Exchange do if this happens?
expected_answer: The Regulator can allow a Recognised Investment Exchange to delay making trade details public for large trades or specific types of trades. If this delay is permitted, the Exchange must inform its Members, users, and investors about the delay and its terms. Even with a delay, the Exchange still needs to make sure that trade details like price, volume, and time are shared with the public and the Regulator as quickly as possible. This includes making sure that details of portfolio trades are shared in a timely way and that information about trades happening outside normal hours is made public before the next trading day starts. These steps help keep the market transparent and fair, even when some details are delayed [#SRC:7f823646-b062-4581-a37a-a39040c4edad] and [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6].

debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must make arrangements for the price, volume and time of transactions executed in Financial Instruments to be made available to the public and the Regulator as close to real-time as technically possible assuming a reasonable level of efficiency and of expenditure on systems on the part of the Recognised Investment Exchange, provided that: (a) information relating to a portfolio trade shall be made available with respect to each constituent transaction as close to real time as possible, having regard to the need to allocate prices to particular Financial Instruments; and (b) post-trade information referring to transactions taking place on a Recognised Investment Exchange but outside its normal trading hours shall be made public before the opening of the next trading day of the Recognised Investment Exchange.

question: What actions must a Relevant Person take to ensure their risk assessment process adequately addresses money laundering risks in NFTF business, considering the need for effective policies and controls?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person must establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems, and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to their activities. This includes ensuring that regular risk assessments are conducted on the adequacy of their AML/TFS systems and controls. These assessments should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with conducting business entirely in an NFTF manner, as distinct risks may arise compared to mixed interaction models. The Relevant Person must ensure that their systems and controls provide necessary management information to their Senior Management, enabling them to identify, measure, manage, and control money laundering risks effectively. Additionally, the systems should enable compliance with applicable rules and legislation, including determining whether a customer or Beneficial Owner is a PEP. The risk assessment should reference mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator and other relevant bodies, ensuring that the systems remain comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale, and complexity of the activities undertaken [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] and [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d].

debug_context.source_text: The risk assessment under Rule 6.2.1(c) should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with undertaking NFTF business generally, and the use of eKYC specifically. This is because distinct risks are often likely to arise where business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner, compared to when the business relationship includes a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions. The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: If a Listed Entity agrees to issue Convertible Securities before its Securities are on the Official List, what must it tell the Regulator, and what needs to happen for the Securities to be officially listed?
expected_answer: When a Listed Entity agrees to issue Convertible Securities before its Securities are on the Official List, it must inform the Regulator about the existence and important details of these Securities in its Approved Prospectus or other documents. This step is necessary to meet regulatory standards. After providing this information, the Securities can only be officially listed once the Regulator publishes their admission. This means the Regulator must add the Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website, making their listing official. This process ensures that the entity meets its disclosure obligations and that the listing procedure is properly followed, providing transparency and regulatory compliance [#SRC:2cf54e06-0e64-49d4-a162-f1fccc69316e] and [#TGT:d28d3376-4af3-4b11-b90d-3f24c8e54555].

question: How should a Recognised Body make sure its business goals don't hurt its Regulatory Functions?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body should have systems and controls in place, including specific policies and procedures, to make sure its business goals, like making a profit, don't negatively affect its Regulatory Functions. It needs to take all reasonable steps to keep its business interests from interfering with its regulatory duties. This means the Recognised Body has to carefully manage its business activities so they don't get in the way of its important regulatory work. By doing this, the Recognised Body can make sure it meets its regulatory responsibilities without letting its business interests cause problems. This involves being careful to avoid any conflicts between making money and doing its regulatory job well, ensuring that its regulatory functions are always done properly and effectively [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] and [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5].

question: If an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession, or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing late, what fee must they pay?
expected_answer: When an Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession, or a Recognised Body submits a Regulatory Filing after the deadline, they must pay a fee of $500 to the Regulator. This fee is required to ensure that all parties comply with the submission deadlines. In addition to this fee, the Regulator may also take further actions if necessary. The fee acts as a penalty for late submissions and encourages timely compliance with regulatory requirements. This ensures that all filings are submitted within the designated timeframes, maintaining the integrity and efficiency of the regulatory process. The imposition of such fees highlights the importance of adhering to deadlines and the consequences of failing to do so [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] and [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187].

question: What must a PFP Operator do about keeping records for six years and updating published information?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator must keep records for at least six years, including all disclosures and documentation related to PFP Clients and transactions. They also need to update any published information to show important changes. After making these updates, they must inform PFP Clients about the changes within a reasonable time. question: How can a Reporting Entity make sure its Corporate Governance framework is good enough, given the Regulator's power to set rules?
expected_answer: To ensure its Corporate Governance framework is adequate, a Reporting Entity needs to follow the rules set by the Regulator. These rules are designed to help the entity manage itself wisely and in the best interest of its shareholders over the long term. The Regulator can specify principles and standards that the Reporting Entity must follow, which apply to its board of Directors, individual members, Controllers, employees, or other relevant people. The entity also needs to make sure it treats its shareholders fairly and has ways to handle conflicts of interest. By doing so, the Reporting Entity can meet the goals of the regulatory framework, as required by the Regulator's rules [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] and the procedures they establish [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d].

Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.

question: Under what conditions may the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree to disregard certain rules related to charges for information, and how does this relate to their ability to set charges for additional information under a Framework Contract?
expected_answer: The Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing to disregard specific rules concerning charges for information when the Customer is not a Natural Person. This agreement allows them to bypass rules such as those related to charges for information, withdrawal of consent, and other specified rules. In conjunction with this, under a Framework Contract, the Third Party Provider and the Customer are permitted to agree on charges for information that is additional to what is required or provided more frequently than specified. This arrangement is applicable when the information is requested by the Customer and is either additional, more frequent, or transmitted through different communication means than those outlined in the Governing Contract. Thus, the ability to disregard certain rules complements the flexibility to agree on additional charges for information, allowing both parties to tailor their contractual obligations and financial arrangements as needed [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] and [#TGT:409ed483-98f6-44e5-812d-17a33796c543].

question: When can the Regulator allow changes to the rule about freely transferring Shares, and what must an Applicant do to get their Securities on the Official List?
expected_answer: The Regulator can allow changes to the rule about freely transferring Shares if there are special circumstances. This can happen if the Applicant can stop the transfer of Shares without causing market problems. But to get their Securities on the Official List, the Applicant must follow certain rules: their Securities need to be properly authorised, have all needed consents, be freely transferable, and if they are Shares, they must be fully paid and without any liens or transfer restrictions. These steps ensure the Securities are valid and can be transferred as required [#TGT:bd978059-6701-4512-8a39-1f9364110d3a] and permitted [#SRC:7b5a94d4-4228-4d1a-b46a-d9f9dab0d14d].

question: Under what conditions may a Customer, who is not a Natural Person, agree with a Third Party Provider that the rules regarding withdrawal of consent do not apply, and how does this relate to the Customer's ability to withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction?
expected_answer: A Customer that is not a Natural Person may agree in writing with a Third Party Provider that specific rules, including those concerning the withdrawal of consent, do not apply. This agreement allows them to bypass the standard regulations that would otherwise govern such transactions. However, under the general permissions, the Customer retains the right to withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the transaction reaches a point where it can no longer be revoked, as specified in the relevant rules. This means that even if certain rules are agreed to be non-applicable, the Customer's ability to withdraw consent remains intact until the transaction becomes irrevocable. This dual framework ensures that while some regulatory requirements can be waived through mutual agreement, the fundamental right to withdraw consent is preserved until a specific point in the transaction process [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] and [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c].

question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person refrain from accepting a Retail Client referral from a Person who is neither an Authorised Person nor a Regulated Financial Institution?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must not accept a referral of a Retail Client made by an unregulated Person where doing so involves the disbursement of a reward, whether monetary or non-monetary in nature, from the Authorised Person to the unregulated Person. This prohibition ensures that financial incentives do not compromise the integrity of client referrals, particularly when the referral originates from a Person not subject to regulatory oversight, such as an unregulated Person. The definition of an unregulated Person is crucial here, as it includes any Person who does not hold the status of an Authorised Person or a Regulated Financial Institution, thereby excluding them from certain regulatory frameworks. This measure is designed to uphold the standards of client protection and market integrity by preventing potential conflicts of interest that may arise from incentivized referrals. By adhering to this prohibition, Authorised Persons contribute to maintaining a fair and transparent financial environment [#SRC:9f819d13-99d4-41f8-8a53-97a67298a01a] and [#TGT:eb92921c-abc1-4657-8789-809b31e91b25].

question: When can't the Regulator share a statement from an interview, and what must the Investigator do to make someone attend that interview?
expected_answer: The Regulator is not allowed to share a statement made during an interview with law enforcement for criminal cases unless the person agrees or a law or court order demands it. This rule helps protect the person's privacy and rights during an investigation. At the same time, the Investigator can require the Person Under Investigation or others to attend an interview by sending a written notice. This notice tells them when and where to go and that they must answer questions. The Investigator can also ask them to bring documents, give information, help with the investigation, or allow the Investigator to visit their business to look at and copy documents. These steps ensure that the investigation is conducted properly while respecting the confidentiality rules that protect the individuals involved [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6] and [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator disqualify an auditor or actuary from serving an Authorised Person or Recognised Body, considering the procedural steps involved?
expected_answer: The Regulator must consider disqualifying an auditor or actuary if it determines that a contravention of the regulations has occurred. The decision-making process involves evaluating the nature and seriousness of the contravention, its impact on customers, and any potential damage to the reputation of the ADGM. Additionally, the Regulator will assess whether the contravention has increased the risk of financial crime within a firm, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity. The Regulator also considers any remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, as well as any disciplinary measures imposed by relevant professional bodies. The auditor's or actuary's previous compliance record and any past disciplinary sanctions are also taken into account. If these considerations lead the Regulator to conclude that the contravention is significant, it may proceed with disqualification from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, or any specific class thereof, as required [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] and permitted [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].

question: What do Reporting Entities need to do to make sure they know about Inside Information and decide if it needs to be disclosed, given that their 'awareness' includes what Officers should reasonably know?
expected_answer: Reporting Entities need to set up effective systems and procedures to ensure they are aware of Inside Information and can decide if it needs to be disclosed. This is important because their 'awareness' now includes not just what their Officers actually know, but also what they should reasonably know. This means that if anyone in the Listed Entity knows something significant, it should be brought to the Officers' attention. Without these systems, a Reporting Entity might delay or avoid its disclosure duties by claiming it didn't know about the Inside Information. Therefore, having the right internal processes and controls is crucial to make sure that any important Inside Information is quickly identified and assessed for disclosure. This helps the Reporting Entity meet its regulatory requirements and ensures timely decision-making [#SRC:515da637-1abc-4870-b98f-7ebda16f0984] and [#TGT:d437551a-aae1-4d57-94a7-fb36d8b2f879].

debug_context.source_text: BECOMING AWARE OF INSIDE INFORMATION In regard to Rule 7.2.1, the first question that an Officer of a Reporting Entity should therefore consider is whether the Reporting Entity is aware of any Inside Information. If yes, that Officer must consider, immediately, whether that Inside Information must be Disclosed. Suitable systems and procedures must therefore be implemented by a Reporting Entity to ensure that Inside Information is promptly identified by, or within, a Listed Entity (in light of the awareness extension discussed in paragraph 38 above) and a decision is taken as to whether a Disclosure is required.
debug_context.target_text: BECOMING AWARE OF INSIDE INFORMATION The extension of a Reporting Entity’s ‘awareness’ to include information that its Officers ‘ought reasonably have come into possession of’ (over and above information that its Officers, in fact, ‘know’) means that a Reporting Entity is considered to be ‘aware’ of Inside Information if the information is known by anyone within the Listed Entity, and is of such significance that it ought reasonably to have been brought to the attention of an Officer of the Listed Entity. Without this extension to the concept of ‘awareness’, a Reporting Entity would be able to avoid, or delay, meeting its continuous disclosure obligations in circumstances where Inside Information had not been brought to the attention of its Officers in a timely manner by others within the Listed Entity. A Listed Entity will need to ensure that it has in place internal systems, processes and controls to ensure that Inside Information is promptly brought to the attention of its Officers.

question: How does the Listing Authority handle the process of issuing an aware letter to a Reporting Entity, and what happens after the Reporting Entity responds?
expected_answer: The Listing Authority may issue an aware letter to a Reporting Entity if it finds that important information wasn't disclosed on time. This happens after checking that the information is correct, is Inside Information, and doesn't qualify for any disclosure exemptions. Once the Reporting Entity replies to the aware letter, the Listing Authority reviews the response. Then, both the aware letter and the response are usually shared with the market. This helps everyone know that the Listing Authority has checked into the Reporting Entity's disclosure timing and what the Reporting Entity had to say about it. This process is important to keep the market informed and ensure that all necessary information is shared as required [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] and [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4].

If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an aware letter (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
debug_context.target_text: SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY Aware Letters When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: What must an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm do to maintain adequate Capital Resources, considering both the Individual Capital Requirement and the nature, size, and complexity of its business?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm is required to maintain adequate Capital Resources by adhering to specific regulatory obligations. This involves ensuring that the Capital Resources are of the types and amounts specified in the relevant rules, and that they are calculated in accordance with these rules. Additionally, the Authorised Person must maintain capital and liquid assets beyond the basic requirement, which are adequate relative to the nature, size, and complexity of its business. This is to ensure that there is no significant risk of failing to meet liabilities as they become due. Furthermore, if an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR) is imposed, the Authorised Person must maintain additional Capital Resources as specified, in compliance with both the ICR and the general capital adequacy requirements. This dual obligation ensures that the firm is well-equipped to handle its financial commitments and regulatory expectations [#SRC:776c1fbb-de2a-4be6-b5fe-7b1666b6abff] and [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56].

debug_context.source_text: Capital ratios. The Regulator may impose a further requirement, termed an Individual Capital Requirement (ICR), on an Authorised Person to hold additional Capital Resources arising from Pillar 2 adjustments (see Chapter 10). Where the Authorised Person has an ICR imposed on it, then the Authorised Person must, at all times, maintain adequate Capital Resources of the type and amount as specified in Rule 10.6.1 in addition to those kept to meet the capital adequacy requirements outlined in Rule 3.2.4.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: What actions must a Fund Manager take if they intend to use passporting procedures and later discover a material change before commencing promotion in a Host Jurisdiction?
expected_answer: If the Fund Manager of a Private Fund intends to utilize the passporting procedures under the applicable Rules, they must first notify the Regulator of their intention for the Private Fund to be recognized as a Passported Fund. Subsequently, if at any time between this notification and the commencement of promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to impact the notification, they are obligated to provide written notice to the Regulator without delay. This ensures that the Regulator can promptly inform the relevant Host Regulator of all pertinent details regarding the material change, error, or omission, thereby maintaining compliance and transparency throughout the passporting process [#TGT:ce022b89-e89b-428c-ba00-4a0fdfea87fb] and [#SRC:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6].

The Regulator will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details of such material change, error or omission.

question: What should a Mining Reporting Entity include in its disclosure about assumptions for financial forecasts, and what must it avoid claiming about commercial sensitivity?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity needs to include all important economic assumptions in its disclosure for financial forecasts. If it believes these assumptions are commercially sensitive, it should say so and explain how it determined them. However, the entity must not claim that information is commercially sensitive if it hasn't made any contracts that would make such claims valid, like those affecting commodity prices or expenses. This means that without these contracts, saying the information is sensitive would be hard to justify. So, while the entity must disclose key assumptions, it should not incorrectly claim they are sensitive, ensuring it follows the rules properly [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95].

(c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case. If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: When can an Authorised Person give better credit terms to a Related Person, even though it's usually not allowed?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can give better credit terms to a Related Person if the credit policy is an Employee credit policy that is available to all Employees. This policy must be approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or someone they delegate. The policy should clearly state the terms, conditions, and limits for giving credit to Employees. It also needs to have ways to make sure the rules are followed, with quick reporting to the Governing Body if there are any problems. This setup allows for giving better credit terms while keeping everything in check, as required [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] and permitted [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496].

debug_context.source_text: Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must: (a) set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit; (b) subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and (c) if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that: (i) require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and (ii) exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: How is market manipulation defined when transactions or orders to trade are executed without legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices, potentially affecting the perception of supply, demand, or price of financial instruments?
expected_answer: Market manipulation is defined as behavior involving the execution of transactions or orders to trade that are not for legitimate reasons and do not conform to Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. This behavior can either give or is likely to give a false or misleading impression regarding the supply, demand, or price of financial instruments, accepted virtual assets, or accepted spot commodities. Alternatively, it can secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level. This definition is crucial as it outlines the conditions under which market manipulation is considered to occur, emphasizing the importance of legitimate reasons and adherence to market practices [#SRC:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b] and [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].

question: Under what circumstances must a Third Party Provider ensure that a Customer is not liable for losses related to unauthorised transactions, considering the obligations regarding Personalised Security Credentials?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider is obligated to ensure that appropriate means are available at all times for a Customer to notify them of any loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Customer's Personalised Security Credentials. This obligation is crucial because if the Third Party Provider fails to provide such means, the Customer is not liable for any losses incurred from unauthorised Third Party Transactions. This non-liability applies unless the Customer has acted fraudulently or with intent or gross negligence in failing to protect their Personalised Security Credentials. Therefore, the Third Party Provider must maintain robust notification systems to protect both their interests and those of the Customer, ensuring that liability does not fall unfairly on the Customer due to the Provider's oversight [#SRC:5adbd32c-9d2c-4fd5-a1e8-060fba49ae90] [#TGT:d8fc441e-0a9e-4a18-bbd8-2cfe0dd0ee07].

debug_context.source_text: Customers liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Except where the Customer has acted fraudulently or has with intent or gross negligence failed to ensure that its Personalised Security Credentials are not accessible to persons other than the Customer, the Customer is not liable for any losses incurred in respect of an unauthorised Third Party Transaction: (a) arising after notification to the Third Party Provider in the agreed manner on becoming aware of the loss, theft, misappropriation or unauthorised use of the Customers Personalised Security Credentials; (b) where the Third Party Provider has failed at any time to provide, in accordance with Rule 20.9.2, appropriate means for notification; or (c) where the Third Party Provider has failed to apply Strong Customer Authentication.
debug_context.target_text: Personalised Security Credentials. A Third Party Provider must ensure that appropriate means are available at all times to enable a Customer to notify the Third Party Provider of the loss, theft, misappropriation or unauthorised use of the Customer’s Personalised Security Credentials.
debug_context.semantic_hook: Customer is not liable for any losses

answer_spans.text: Personalised Security Credentials.

question: Under what circumstances must an Insider not disclose Inside Information to another person, considering both the proper course of employment and regulatory prohibitions?
expected_answer: An Insider is prohibited from disclosing Inside Information to another person unless it is done in the proper course of their employment, profession, or duties. This prohibition is grounded in regulatory requirements that aim to prevent the misuse of sensitive information. The regulation specifies that any disclosure outside the proper course of one's professional responsibilities is not allowed. This ensures that Inside Information is not improperly shared, which could lead to unfair advantages or market manipulation. The rule is clear that such disclosures must align with the Insider's professional obligations and duties, and any deviation from this standard is not permissible. This dual emphasis on the proper course of employment and regulatory compliance underscores the importance of maintaining confidentiality and integrity in handling Inside Information [#SRC:8f77978a-8215-43c3-a41b-20e6843ea3a6] [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b].

question: When can an Authorised Person recognise the CRM effects of a guarantee from an MDB, and what must they do with CR Exposures to these MDBs?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can recognise the CRM effects of a guarantee if it is provided by certain entities, including multilateral development banks (MDBs) mentioned in the rules. For CR Exposures to these qualifying MDBs, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight. This means that when the guarantee is from an MDB like the World Bank Group or the Asian Development Bank, the exposure is considered very low risk, and the Authorised Person must follow the rule to apply no risk weight to it. This ensures that the financial stability and risk management practices are maintained as required by the regulations [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] and permitted by the conditions set for recognising CRM effects [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d].

question: What obligations must an MTF fulfill to ensure users of its market can access Inside Information, and how must an Issuer provide a Product Summary Note in an Exempt Offer context?
expected_answer: An MTF that admits Securities for trading under an Exempt Offer must have effective systems and controls to allow market users access to Inside Information, including relevant Offer documents. This ensures transparency and compliance with applicable rules. Concurrently, the Issuer involved in an Exempt Offer must provide a Product Summary Note to investors, which highlights key information from the Offer document and includes a prominent disclaimer. The Note must be clear, balanced, and free from misleading statements, aligning with the Offer document's content. The Issuer is also required to notify the Regulator of its intention to provide this Note at least ten Business Days before the Offer. These combined obligations ensure that both the MTF and the Issuer maintain a high standard of information dissemination and regulatory compliance, facilitating informed decision-making by investors [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] and [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2].

debug_context.source_text: An MTF that admits to trading Securities that are offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) shall ensure that it has effective systems and controls in place to: (a) admit only Securities of such Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform; (b) identify those Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made; (c) restrict trading of the Securities, to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; (d) comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading), as applicable in relation to the relevant Securities; and (e) allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.5 relevant to the Securities.
debug_context.target_text: Pursuant to an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer must provide a Product Summary Note to investors in accordance with the following requirements: (1) The Product Summary Note must: (a) highlight key information in the Offer document to investors; (b) clearly disclose required information in the format as set out in APP 7; (c) give a fair and balanced view of the nature, material benefits and material risks of the Securities offered; (d) not contain any statement or information that is false or misleading in the form and context in which it is included; (e) be given together with the Offer document to investors. If the Issuer makes the Offer document available online, the Product Summary Note must be made available online together with the Offer document; (f) not contain any information that is not contained in the Offer document; (g) not contain any Inside Information that differs in any material particular from that set out in the Offer document; and (h) not omit any information from any part of the Product Summary Note which would result in that part of the Product Summary Note being construed as false or misleading. (2) The Product Summary Note shall contain the prominent disclaimer set out in Rule 4.3.4 in bold, on its front. (3) The Issuer must give notice the Regulator of its intention to provide a Product Summary Note at least ten Business Days prior to the Exempt Offer, in such form as the Regulator may prescribe. (4) When the Issuer makes any change to the Offer document, the Product Summary Note must be updated if the change has a material effect on the key information of the Securities offered. (5) Issuers must ensure there is clear naming of the Securities offered. The name of the Securities must be descriptive of the nature of the Securities offered. It must not give investors a misleading view of the true nature and risks of the Securities offered.
